title: How to Make Oatmeal and Coconut Biscuits

steps.headline: Beat together (using an electric hand beater) the butter, brown sugar, white sugar, vanilla extract and egg in a small bowl.
steps.description: Beat thoroughly until well combined. Make sure that everything is evenly distributed. Remember to omit the egg if you are using vanilla sugar.

steps.headline: Sift the flour into another bowl.
steps.description: Make sure you allow air to get into the flour. When sifting, hold the sieve approximately 20cm (8 inches) from the bowl. If you hold it too high, you will end up losing some flour.

steps.headline: Add the baking powder, salt, oats and desiccated coconut to the bowl with the flour and stir together gently.
steps.description: Make sure it is well combined. Avoid stirring the ingredients together too much as the flour may clump up again and the biscuit will not be as light.

steps.headline: Stir the dry mixture into the butter mixture.
steps.description: Use a wooden spoon or silicone spatula to fold the mixture together. Continue mixing until everything has completely combined. At this stage, your mixture may be a bit dry. Add a small amount of milk to help it come together.

steps.headline: Line a baking tray with baking paper (parchment paper).
steps.description: Make sure you're not using greaseproof paper as it's not suitable for baking biscuits—greaseproof paper cannot withstand high heat.

steps.headline: Scoop out biscuit mixture with a teaspoon and place each piece of dough on the baking paper.
steps.description: Ensure that you leave plenty of space between each biscuit as the biscuits will expand. You will not want to have one giant biscuit.

steps.headline: Sprinkle the extra desiccated coconut over the biscuits and place the tray in the oven to bake for about 10 minutes.
steps.description: If possible, place the biscuits on the middle rack of your oven. Remember to watch the biscuits very carefully to ensure that they don't burn.

steps.headline: Take the tray out of the oven and transfer the biscuits to a cooling rack.
steps.description: Be careful when doing this as the oven will be fairly hot. Use a tea towel or oven mitt to hold the tray while taking it out.

steps.headline: Allow the biscuits to cool for a few minutes before serving.

text: Preheat your oven to 180°C (350°F).  Beat together (using an electric hand beater) the butter, brown sugar, white sugar, vanilla extract and egg in a small bowl. Beat thoroughly until well combined. Make sure that everything is evenly distributed. Remember to omit the egg if you are using vanilla sugar. Sift the flour into another bowl. Make sure you allow air to get into the flour. When sifting, hold the sieve approximately 20cm (8 inches) from the bowl. If you hold it too high, you will end up losing some flour. Add the baking powder, salt, oats and desiccated coconut to the bowl with the flour and stir together gently. Make sure it is well combined. Avoid stirring the ingredients together too much as the flour may clump up again and the biscuit will not be as light. Stir the dry mixture into the butter mixture. Use a wooden spoon or silicone spatula to fold the mixture together. Continue mixing until everything has completely combined. At this stage, your mixture may be a bit dry. Add a small amount of milk to help it come together. Line a baking tray with baking paper (parchment paper). Make sure you're not using greaseproof paper as it's not suitable for baking biscuits—greaseproof paper cannot withstand high heat. Scoop out biscuit mixture with a teaspoon and place each piece of dough on the baking paper. Ensure that you leave plenty of space between each biscuit as the biscuits will expand. You will not want to have one giant biscuit. Sprinkle the extra desiccated coconut over the biscuits and place the tray in the oven to bake for about 10 minutes. If possible, place the biscuits on the middle rack of your oven. Remember to watch the biscuits very carefully to ensure that they don't burn. Take the tray out of the oven and transfer the biscuits to a cooling rack. Be careful when doing this as the oven will be fairly hot. Use a tea towel or oven mitt to hold the tray while taking it out. Allow the biscuits to cool for a few minutes before serving. Enjoy!
